[Cu(acac)(phen)(H2O)](ClO4) and [Cu(acac)(bipy)(H2O)](ClO4) catalysts were prepared by the immobilization of mixed-ligand complexes on graphene oxide derivatized with monochloroacetic acid. These catalysts were characterized through an ensemble of techniques including XRD, FTIR, Raman, and XPS while the catalytic behavior has been investigated in the oxidation of cyclohexene, 1-octene and glycerol in the presence of molecular oxygen. Cyclohexanone was the dominant product in the oxidation of cyclohexene resulting in selectivities higher than 50% for a conversion of 14.5%. The turnover frequencies were pretty high, namely, 4.5 h−1 for [Cu(acac)(phen)(H2O)](ClO4) and 2.3 h−1 for Cu(acac)(bipy)(H2O)](ClO4). The oxidation of 1-octene also occurred with a pretty high selectivity in 2-octanol as the main product. The role of copper in the oxidative dehydrogenation of glyceric acid towards tartronic acid was as well confirmed. Noteworthy, these catalysts were stable and their recycling occurred with no change in the conversion or selectivity. Graphical abstract ga1 Keywords Selective oxidation of cyclohexene and 1-octene by oxygen Copper complexes immobilized through the carboxylato groups of GO XRD, FTIR, Raman, and XPS characterization Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction The selective catalytic C–H oxidation is one of the most important reactions from both the industrial and research perspective. Thus, the selective oxidation may afford the conversion of common and cheap hydrocarbons into valuable functionalized compounds, of interest for the production of chemicals, pharmaceuticals, fragrances, etc. [1]. In addition, oxidants as hydrogen peroxide or molecular oxygen provide environmentally friendly and high atom efficient solutions [2,3]. Particularly, molecular oxygen presents additional advantages such as a low price (also air can often be used in these reactions), but also disadvantages like special precautions required for large scale applications, especially at high pressures [4]. Relied to the sustainable and environmentally safe conditions, the use of molecular oxygen for the functionalization of organic compounds brings to discussion certain challenges among the most important ones are: i) the activation of the C–H bond, ii) the activation of the oxygen molecule and iii) the participation of the solvent. The activation of the aliphatic C–H bonds in hydrocarbons is rather difficult due to their thermodynamic stability [1]. However, for the unsaturated compounds like olefins or arenes, this step can be done in an easier way through the coordination of the unsaturated bond by an active metal in a complex, followed by its rupture [5]. The activation of the oxygen molecule could be also accomplished by complexes with transition metals. A good example in this sense is the gas phase oxidation of ethylene to ethylene oxide over Ag supported catalyst, ie a reaction occurring through a Ag-dioxygen complex of ethylene. However, organic reactions with dioxygen in the ground state are limited by spin conservation, a problem which may be overcome by the intermediate formation of metal complexes, especially, with transition metals [6]. The solvent is also important in these reactions because the open coordination site depends on it, and the stability of the dioxygen adduct is affected by its interaction with the solvent. Related to this, the stability of the adduct depends on the shielding effect of the ligand substituent groups around the coordinated dioxygen. All these factors can influence the interaction between a catalyst and dioxygen and, therefore, to make it predictable, it is important to generate a proper environment around the metal. Such an objective can be achieved through the design of a proper ligand system and selected reaction conditions [7]. As for a metal, the complexes of the first row of transition metals showed a large interest for the catalytic oxidations. Among these, compared to other metals, the complexes of copper were largely investigated due to its abundance, reduced toxicity and lower cost [8]. Its participation in these reactions is related to either a direct involvement of the metal center or of the preformed copper complexes [9]. However, the stability of the copper–dioxygen complexes depends to a large extent on the nature of the used ligands depending on factors such as the donor set, geometry, substituent electronic and steric effects, chelate size [7]. Another important factor controlling the interaction between the copper complex and oxygen is the oxidation potential of the Cu(I)–Cu(II) couple. Kinetic factors can also influence the binding rate of dioxygen to the copper center depending on the existence of an open coordination site. Chemical composition of the ligands is another important factor, and the ligands with nitrogen are among the most active for oxidation reactions [10]. 2,2′-Bipyridine and 1,10-phenanthroline are examples of nitrogen-containing ligands that are often used as chelating agents for such applications [11]. Immobilization of these complexes onto large porous supports as mesoporous silicas allowed the epoxidation of cyclohexene with TBHP [12] or phenol and anisole with hydrogen peroxide [13]. Graphene derived materials, such as graphene oxide, have also been investigated as supports for the selective oxidation of organic compounds. Thus, the allylic oxidation of cyclohexene with molecular oxygen has been carried out in the presence of nanometric metal oxide particles catalysts supported on porous nitrogen-doped carbons [14]. Also, many metal complexes have been immobilized onto carbonaceous materials and tested in various other organic reactions as recyclable catalysts [15]. Recent studies have been also focused to derived carbonaceous materials as supports for Cu NPs [16] in various catalytic applications as cycloadditions, couplings, reduction or oxidation reactions [17]. Based on this state of the art, the present study investigated some copper complexes grafted onto functionalized GO and their capability for the selective heterogeneous catalytic oxidation of model compounds such as linear (1-octene) and cyclic alkenes (cyclohexene). To further explore the efficacy of these catalysts, the oxidation of polyalcohols (glycerol) with molecular oxygen was as well considered. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of the catalysts All the utilized chemicals were of Sigma-Aldrich purity. Graphene oxide (GO) was synthesised from graphite (Graphite, flakes, 99% carbon basis, −325 mesh particle size) following a modified Hummer’s route [18] ( Scheme 1). 2.93 g of KMnO4 were slowly added, under a continuous stirring, to a suspension containing 0.5 g graphite, 60 mL H2SO4 (98%) and 7 mL H3PO4. After 6 h, 1.5 mL of H2O2 were drop-wise added and the mixture was finally treated with a solution of 25 mL HCl /70 mL H2O. Then, the supernatant was separated by centrifugation and washed three times with water and hydrochloric acid. The resulted graphene oxide was dried in an oven at 50 °C for 12 h. The solid was further functionalized through a derivatization with monochloroacetic acid (GOCOOH) [19] followed by the deposition of the copper complex. Thus, 50 mL of an aqueous suspension of GO-COOH (4 g/L) deprotonated with 5 drops of triethylamine, were stirred with a methanolic solution (20 mL) of [Cu(acac)(phen)(H2O)]+(ClO4)- (0.326 mmols), respectively, [Cu(acac)(bipy)(H2O)]+(ClO4)- (0.344 mmols) for 24 h at room temperature [20,21]. Finally, these materials were washed with methanol and dried at 60 °C [22]. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The catalysts were characterized through an ensemble of techniques including XRD, FTIR, Raman, and XPS. Powder XRD patterns were collected with a Shimadzu XRD-7000 diffractometer employing the CuKα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) operating at 40 kV and a current intensity of 40 mA in the 2θ range of 5 – 90°. FTIR spectra of the fresh and tested graphene catalysts were acquired in the spectral region 500–4000 cm−1 with a Brucker Tensor II spectrometer with a Praying Mantis accessory, while the Raman spectra were measured in the extended spectral region from 150 to 4000 cm−1 using a Horiba JobinYvon–Labram HR UV–Vis-NIR Raman Microscope Spectrophotometer, excited with a laser at 488 nm. X-Ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) on the samples was carried out with a Kratos AXIS Ultra DLD system equipped with a hemispherical analyzer with a reference intensity of over 50,000 counts per second (cps) and spectral resolution of 0.6 eV, using Al Kα1 (1486.74 eV) radiation produced by a mono-chromatized X-Ray source with spot size of 0.7 mm. The operating power was 192 W (12 kV x 16 mA) and the spectra were recorded with 160 eV pass energy for surveys and 40 eV pass energy for high resolution measurements, with Hybrid lens mode and slot aperture. Partial charge compensation was achieved using a neutralizer flood gun (filament current of 1.8 A, charge balance of 2.7 V, filament bias of 1.02 V). The base pressure in the analysis chamber before measurements was in low 10−9 mbar. The above parameters were optimized in order to obtain the C 1 s peak of the carbon contamination of the sample at 284.60 ± 0.01 eV. (C1 +1.96, C2 +1.758, C3 +2.087, C4 +1.759, C5 +1.166, C6 +1.816, C7 +1.599). Peaks were resolved with IGOR software and assigned by considering reliable literature reports. The spectra were fitted using Voigt peak profiles. The amplitude was corrected with ASF – atomic sensitivity factors for XPS [23]. 2.3 Catalytic tests The catalytic tests were performed under stirring conditions in a batch autoclave from Hell using 3.3 mg of catalyst and 1 mL of substrate. The experiments were carried out at 80 and 120 °C, respectively, under a pressure of O2 of 20 bars, in a range of time from 24 to 48 h taking cyclohexene, 1-octene and glycerol (Sigma-Aldrich purity) as substrates. As a solvent, for cyclohexene and 1-octene it was used n-heptane (Sigma-Aldrich purity, 5 mL), and water for glycerol (5 mL). Before pressurization, the autoclave was flushed several times with O2. The reactants and products were analyzed using a GC-FID apparatus equipped with a non-polar GC capillary column (J&W DB-5 ms, 50 m × 0.20 mm × 0.33 µm) operating with H2 as the carrier gas. The temperature profile was set to 2 min dwell at 50 °C and 5 °C min ramp up to 250 °C, followed by a 2 min dwell. 3 Results and discussion The synthesis of the two catalysts is based on the observation that the acetylacetonato ligand from [Cu(acac)(AA)](ClO4) complexes (AA = 2,2-bipyridine; 1,10-phenanthroline), are easily replaced by carboxylato ligands (see Scheme 1) [24]. 3.1 Characterization of the catalysts 3.1.1 XRD Fig. 1 presents the patterns of the investigated catalysts taking as reference both the GO and GOCOOH supports and the [Cu(acac)(phen)(H2O)](ClO4) complex. As it can be seen, all of these patterns presented the typical diffraction line at 2θ ∼ 9.5° corresponding to the (002) plane of the graphene oxide. The position of this line may also offer information about the intercalation of the functional groups containing oxygen into the layers could mean that the interlayer spacing might be extended due to. Furthermore, it can also be observed the characteristic lines of the (002) reflection planes of graphite at 2θ ∼24.5° [25]. The low intensity line at 2θ ∼43° corresponds to the facet (100) of carbon and is associated with a partial reduction. Finally, the lines in the range 2θ 8–10° and around 2θ 14° correspond to the (200), (220) and (400) facets of the copper complexes [26] . 3.1.2 FTIR spectra The FT-IR spectra of GO ( Figs. 2 and 3, a) present a broad band in the range 3200 – 3700 cm−1 ascribed to the stretching vibrations of the constituent OH groups and absorbed water molecules [27]. The bands at 1726, 1218 and 1056 cm−1 are associated to the stretching vibrations of the oxygenated CO, C-OH C-O functional fragments [28]. while that at 1631 cm−1 to the stretching vibration of CC [29]. The derivatization by monochloroacetic acid ((Figs. 2 and 3, b) corresponded to an increase of the population of carboxylate groups as confirmed by the presence of two stronger absorption bands at 1722 and 2923 cm−1 (assigned to CH2) [30]. (d) [Cu(acac)(phen)(H2O)](ClO4). (d) [Cu(acac)(bipy)(H2O)](ClO4). Figs. 2 and 3 (c,d) shows the FT-IR spectra of GO-COOH/Cu(L) and of the complexes. The immobilization of the [Cu(acac)(AA)(ClO4) complexes (AA = phen, bipy) onto GOCOOH has been confirmed by a decrease in the intensity of the CO band (1720 cm−1) and the presence of the new bands. In the case of GOCOOH/Cu(phen) the FTIR spectra (Fig. 2 , c) revealed characteristic bands of 1,10-phenanthroline at 842 and 715 cm−1 corresponding to the C-H stretching vibrations and at 1567 cm−1 corresponding to C-N bond. Similarly, for GOCOOH/Cu(bipy) (Fig. 3 , c), the bands at 767 and 1565 cm−1 are attributed to C-H and C-N bonds in 2,2′-bipyridine. The presence of uncoordinated perchlorate anion in both complexes was evidenced by the bands at 1080 and 620 cm−1. Also, the shift in the position of these bands compared to free complexes provided another proof of the anchorage of the complexes onto the GOCOOH surface. Concluding, the anchoring of the [Cu(acac)(phen)(H2O)](ClO4) and [Cu(acac)(bipy)(H2O)](ClO4) complexes onto carboxylated graphene oxide surface is the effect of their already demonstrated ability to react with the carboxylic groups from the graphene oxide surface through the replacement of the acetylacetonate ligand. 3.1.3 Raman spectra Raman spectra through exciting with a laser at 488 nm were recorded for both fresh and tested catalysts. For the fresh catalysts ( Fig. 4 , a), the spectra are compatible with a graphene-like structure, presenting the D band at ∼1350 cm−1, G band at ∼1580 cm−1 and the G′ band at ∼2700 cm−1. By comparison, Fig. 4 , b presents the Raman spectra for spent catalysts. Compared to the fresh catalysts, besides the lines assigned to a graphene-type structure, these spectra showed three additional lines at ∼290, ∼390 and ∼730 cm−1 where that at ∼290 cm−1 corresponds to Cu-O bond [31], at ∼390 cm−1 to the Cu–N stretching modes [32]. Fig. 5 shows the XPS spectra of the fresh (a and e) and tested (b-d, and f) catalysts in the region of the Cu2p energy level. The XPS binding energy of the Cu 2p3/2 level was deconvoluted in two components corresponding to Cu(II) at 934.0 eV and Cu(I) at 932.8 eV. For the fresh catalysts, the ratio of the these components was different, being around 64% for the sample 1 and around 87% for the sample 2 in the favor of the Cu(II) species. These differences can be explained through the coordination of metal atoms with the phenanthroline nitrogen resulting in a modification in the electronic density around the metal atoms [33,34]. No major changes were evidenced for the two catalysts after the catalytic tests in the oxidation of cyclohexene (Fig. 5 , a, b, e and f). However, the oxidation of the 1-octene and especially of glycerol changed the Cu(II)/Cu(I) ratios of these catalysts, and the Cu(I) species became dominant thus confirming their direct participation in the catalytic cycle (Fig. 5 , c and d). 3.2 Catalytic activity 3.2.1 Oxidation of cyclohexene The oxidation of cyclohexene followed two parallel routes, namely, allylic oxidation and epoxidation. However, in a second step, the epoxidation products can be further oxidized to different derivatives ( Scheme 2). Graphene oxide is not an inert material in this process and previous studies already reported its catalytic capability to oxidize cyclohexene following both the allylic and epoxidation routes [35]. The oxidation behavior of such materials is, however, related to their pre-treatment conditions. Without any pre-activation, like in this case, the conversion of cyclohexene was below 2%. Further deposition of the copper-bis-acetylacetonate complex onto the graphene oxide led to a certain increase of the conversion, however, this remaining below 4%. This behavior is somehow connected to the capability of this complex to activate molecular oxygen [36] . Finally, the immobilization of the Cu(acac)(phen)(H2O)](ClO4) (1) and Cu(acac)(bipy)(H2O)](ClO4) (2) complexes led to an additional increase of the conversion of cyclohexene ( Figs. 6–9 ) and also to changes in the selectivity. The presence of the co-ligand, namely, phenanthroline or bipyridine, afforded an enhancement of the activity demonstrated by an increase of the conversion [37] . In both cases, cyclohexanone was the dominant reaction product (over 50% selectivity for a conversion of cyclohexene of 14.5%) and 2-cyclohexenol the second as importance (over 20% as selectivity). However, these results showed that the effect of the phenanthroline as co-ligand was more effective compared to bipyridine. Besides these products, small amounts of cyclohexene oxide (3), 2-cyclohexenol (2), 1,2-cyclohexanediol and 1,2-cyclo-hexadione (4), 2-hydroxy-cyclohexanone (5), and 2,3-epoxy-1-cyclohexenol (6) were as well identified. The selectivity changed with the increase of the temperature and the reaction time. As an example, 1,2-cyclohexanediol was well evidenced at 80 °C, while the increase of the temperature at 120 °C led to its oxidation to 1,2-cyclo-hexadione. The calculation of the turnover frequency (TOF) indicated pretty high values for such reactions, namely, 4.5 h−1 for Cu(acac)(phen)(H2O)](ClO4) and 2.3 h−1 for Cu(acac)(bipy)(H2O)](ClO4). 3.2.2 Oxidation of 1-octene Further, the catalytic behavior of the immobilized [Cu(acac)(phen)(H2O)](ClO4) (1) and [Cu(acac)(bipy)(H2O)](ClO4) (2) complexes was evaluated for the oxidation with molecular oxygen of 1-octene ( Scheme 3 , Figs. 9 and 10). The conversion at 80 °C was rather small, just a little over 3% after 48 h. However, rising the temperature to 120 °C led to an increase of the conversion to almost 9% for the complex with phenantroline that is rather satisfactory. Regarding the selectivity, 2-octanol was the main product, but also different amounts of 1,2-epoxyoctane, 3-octanone, 2-octanone and n-octanol were produced. As expected, the selectivity changed with the increase of the temperature and the reaction time, but 2-octanol remained the main product in all cases. Finally, the catalytic behavior of the immobilized [Cu(acac)(phen)(H2O)](ClO4) (1) and [Cu(acac)(bipy)(H2O)](ClO4) (2) complexes onto the carboxylated graphene oxide surface was evaluated for the oxidation of glycerol with molecular oxygen. The oxidation of glycerol occurred only at temperatures higher than 120 °C ( Fig. 11 ). At this temperature, after 48 h, the conversion exceeded 60% for (1) and around 50% for (2), the conversion being much higher compared to those for the oxidation of cyclohexene or 1-octene. Concerning the selectivity, the oxidation of glycerol was rather unselective occurring with the production of all the molecules depicted in Scheme 4. However, the oxidation to glyceraldehyde and the derived acids occurred only on the catalysts with copper, not on graphene oxide, that is in accordance with previous reports indicating the oxidative dehydrogenation of glyceric acid towards tartronic acid, also confirming the role of copper in this process [39] . Reaction conditions: 1 mL glycerol, 1 mL H 2 O as solvent, 3.3 mg catalyst, 120 °C, initial O 2 . pressure 20 atm, 800 rpm, 1.5 mol/l K 2 CO 3 . In order to get an insight into the reaction mechanism and to check the presence of the free-radicals in the bulky solution we considered the experimental procedure proposed by Denekamp et al. [14]. Accordingly, 2,6-di-tert-butyl-4-methylphenol (BHT) was used as a free-radical scavenger in the solution. A comparison with the reaction in the absence of BHT reagent indicated only a slight decrease in both the conversion and selectivity. This result indicates that both the GO-COOH/Cu(phen) and GO-COOH/Cu(Bipy) catalysts were not affected by the free-radical scavengers, that is also in accordance to the report of Denekamp et al. [14]. Based on these results, we proposed that the activated surface oxygen species (e.g., O2 -∙ radical anions) are close enough to diffuse to the Cu active sites where react with cyclohexene with the formation of hydroperoxide. Further, the adsorbed hydroperoxide intermediates decompose into the reaction products. A hot filtration test was performed to ascertain that the catalytic reaction is driven only by the active sites located on the solid catalyst surface. The test was performed under the optimized reaction conditions as following: a reaction mixture containing GO-COOH/Cu(phen) and cyclohexene (1 mL n-heptane as solvent, 3.3 mg catalyst, T 120 °C, PO2= 20 atm O2, 800 rpm.) was run for 6 h, at 120 °C and then, after 30 min, the GO-COOH/Cu(phen) catalyst was removed from the reaction mixture. Then, the reaction was continued for another 6 h and aliquots were periodically withdrawn for the analysis by GC. The comparison of the results with and without catalyst confirmed that, indeed, in the absence of the catalyst the reaction was totally inhibited. These results also indicate that no active species leached in the solution, that also confirmed that the reaction is promoted by the active sites of the GO-COOH/Cu(phen) catalyst. Also important, the catalysts were stable and their recycling occurred with no change in the conversion or selectivity. 4 Conclusions [Cu(acac)(phen)(H2O)](ClO4)-GO] (1) and [Cu(acac)(bipy)(H2O)](ClO4)-GO] (2) catalysts were prepared by the immobilization of the complexes after the derivatization of graphene oxide with monochloroacetic acid followed by the deposition of copper. The resulted catalysts were characterized through an ensemble of techniques including XRD, FTIR, Raman, and X-Ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy. The catalytic behavior of these materials has been investigated in the oxidation of cyclohexene, 1-octene and glycerol in the presence of molecular oxygen. For cyclohexene, cyclohexanone was the dominant reaction product resulting in selectivities higher than 50% for a conversion of 14.5%. 2-cyclohexenol was the second product as importance with selectivities higher than 20%. The calculation of the turnover frequency indicated pretty high values for such reactions, namely, 4.5 h−1 for Cu(acac)(phen)(H2O)](ClO4) and 2.3 h−1 for Cu(acac)(bipy)(H2O)](ClO4). The oxidation of 1-octene occurred at 120 °C with a conversion of 9% and pretty high selectivity in 2-octanol as the main product (over 50%). Finally, the oxidation to glyceraldehyde and the derived acids occurred rather unselective. However, these reactions confirmed the role of copper in the oxidative dehydrogenation of glyceric acid towards tartronic acid. The catalysts were stable and their recycling occurred with no change in the conversion or selectivity. coredata.dc:description: [Cu(acac)(phen)(H2O)](ClO4) and [Cu(acac)(bipy)(H2O)](ClO4) catalysts were prepared by the immobilization of mixed-ligand complexes on graphene oxide derivatized with monochloroacetic acid. These catalysts were characterized through an ensemble of techniques including XRD, FTIR, Raman, and XPS while the catalytic behavior has been investigated in the oxidation of cyclohexene, 1-octene and glycerol in the presence of molecular oxygen. Cyclohexanone was the dominant product in the oxidation of cyclohexene resulting in selectivities higher than 50% for a conversion of 14.5%. The turnover frequencies were pretty high, namely, 4.5 h−1 for [Cu(acac)(phen)(H2O)](ClO4) and 2.3 h−1 for Cu(acac)(bipy)(H2O)](ClO4). The oxidation of 1-octene also occurred with a pretty high selectivity in 2-octanol as the main product. The role of copper in the oxidative dehydrogenation of glyceric acid towards tartronic acid was as well confirmed. Noteworthy, these catalysts were stable and their recycling occurred with no change in the conversion or selectivity.
coredata.dc:title: Liquid phase oxidation of alkenes and glycerol with molecular oxygen over mixed-ligand copper(II) complexes grafted on GO as catalysts

dcterms:subject.$: Selective oxidation of cyclohexene and 1-octene by oxygen
Copper complexes immobilized through the carboxylato groups of GO
XRD, FTIR, Raman, and XPS characterization
